title.rendered: From Picasso, Frida Kahlo, NFTs, to a coin: the best of 2021 auctions

content.rendered:
What were the best auctioned objects in 2021? Here we present a list of the most significant auctions of the year

Newsroom / Mexico City

The auction market has easily recovered from the pandemic in 2021, a year marked by several multi-million dollar records and in which everything from paintings by Pablo Picasso, Frida Kahlo or Boticelli, to Michael Jordan sneakers, extraordinary coins and art stand out. digital format in the innovative NFT format, which attracted many glances.

Here is a list of the most significant auctions of 2021:

Femme assise près d’une fenêtre (Marie-Thérèse) – Picasso

The most valuable item auctioned for the year was a large, vibrantly colored portrait of Picasso, Femme assise près d’une fenêtre (Marie-Thérèse), which came close to doubling the estimated price of $55 million. calculated by the experts at Christie’s auction house, and that it ended up selling for 103.4 million dollars in New York.

In This Case – ean-Michel Basquiat

In This Case, a painting by Haitian-born American Jean-Michel Basquiat, fetched a final price of $93.1 million. The painting was the last in a series of three paintings of skulls that Basquiat painted in 1983, and had been in the hands of fashion designer and Valentino co-founder Giancarlo Giammetti.

Young man holding a medallion – Botticelli

Botticelli was another of the stars of the year’s auctions, selling for $92.1 million an extraordinary painting by the Italian Renaissance, Young Man Holding a Medallion, which had not been sold to the highest bidder since 1982 and had only been on the market four times. in 200 years.

Everyday: The First 5,000 Days – Beeple

NFTs, digital assets that thanks to blockchain technology are registered as unique and irreplicable, burst onto the market in 2021, but it was the artist Beeple who took the cake in this format by selling his Everyday: The First 5,000 Days for 69.3 million dollars.

Diego and I – Diego and I

The self-portrait Diego and I, from c, marked a record price for a work by a Latin American artist at auction, when it was sold at Sotheby’s in New York for 34.9 million dollars, also quadrupling the previous historical maximum of the painter herself Mexican of 8 million dollars achieved in 2016.

A copy of the first definitive text of the United States Constitution was auctioned for more than 43.2 million dollars, becoming the most expensive historical document to be acquired in a sale to the highest bidder, double the maximum price estimated by Sotheby’s experts.

On the other hand, a 1933 Double Eagle coin was auctioned for 18.9 million dollars in New York, the most expensive in history to be sold to the highest bidder after notably exceeding the 15 million dollars maximum value that had been awarded. . The piece is considered the “Mona Lisa of coins”, according to Sotheby’s representatives, because it is the only one of its kind that is still in private hands, since the rest are owned by the United States Mint.

A pair of sneakers worn at a game in 1984 by Michael Jordan have sold at Sotheby’s auction for a record price of nearly $1.5 million.
The shoes, white and red, were used by Jordan in the fifth game of his first season in the NBA as a Chicago Bulls player, in 1984, and are signed by him.

And, finally, one of the surprises of the year was the painting Upstairs Interior, by the American artist Hilary Pecis, 42, which was sold at a Sotheby’s auction in New York for 870 thousand dollars, ten times more than the price estimated by experts.
